title: 114_s3191
content:
The "Rural Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 2016" establishes a core set of rural health care quality measures and makes revisions to Medicare rural grants. It also includes rural-based payment reforms. The "Rural Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 2016" integrates rural health care quality measures into payment models, tests financial incentives for rural providers to submit quality data, and explores value-based payment models and readmissions reduction programs for rural hospitals. Additionally, it allows rural health clinics and Federally qualified health centers to participate in the Comprehensive Primary Care Plus model. Title I of the "Rural Health Care Quality Improvement Act of 2016" establishes a core set of rural health care quality measures under Title XVIII of the Social Security Act. This includes provisions for rural representation on various healthcare councils and commissions. The Secretary is required to establish a core set of quality measures for rural providers by January 1, 2018. These measures focus on improving patient outcomes, care coordination, cost reduction, patient safety, preventive care services, chronic disease management, and other specified purposes. The Secretary must establish a core set of quality measures for rural providers by January 1, 2018, focusing on improving patient outcomes, care coordination, cost reduction, patient safety, preventive care services, chronic disease management, and other specified purposes. The core measures should align with existing quality reporting requirements to reduce reporting burdens for small rural providers. Annual updating of the core set of quality measures will be conducted by the Secretary. The Secretary will annually review and update the core set of quality measures for rural providers to ensure reliability and validity. Additionally, a conforming amendment to the Social Security Act includes rural health care quality measures starting in 2019. SEC. 102. REVISIONS TO MEDICARE RURAL GRANTS. Revisions to Medicare rural grants include amendments to the Social Security Act for appropriations to the HI trust fund and grants for emergency medical services in rural communities. Additionally, there are grants for technical assistance in quality improvement reporting by critical access hospitals. The Social Security Act is amended to provide grants for technical assistance in quality improvement reporting by critical access hospitals. These grants aim to help hospitals establish or expand quality improvement reporting programs and provide necessary support. Critical access hospitals must submit an application to the Secretary to be eligible for these grants. The Secretary specifies reporting requirements for critical access hospitals receiving grants. Hospitals must submit relevant quality data annually to continue receiving grants. Data will be made public, and hospitals have the opportunity to review it before publication. The Secretary will report quality measures related to hospitals on the CMS website, including process, structure, outcome, patients' perspective, efficiency, and costs of care. TITLE II--RURAL-BASED PAYMENT REFORMS

SEC. 201. INTEGRATING RURAL HEALTH CARE QUALITY MEASURES INTO PAYMENT MODELS:
Amends the Social Security Act to include rural health care quality measures in alternative payment models and value-based payment demonstration projects.

SEC. 202. CENTER FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID INNOVATION TESTING FINANCIAL INCENTIVES FOR RURAL PROVIDERS:
Establishes testing for financial incentives for rural providers to submit data on quality measures. Section 1115A of the Social Security Act is amended to include a model providing financial incentives for rural providers to submit data on quality measures. This is part of the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation testing of value-based payment models for rural providers of services and suppliers. SEC. 203 amends Section 1115A of the Social Security Act to test value-based payment models for rural providers of services and suppliers. SEC. 204 focuses on testing a hospital readmissions reduction program for rural hospitals. SEC. 204 amends Section 1115A of the Social Security Act to test a hospital readmissions reduction program for rural hospitals. SEC. 205 allows rural health clinics and Federally qualified health centers to participate in the Comprehensive Primary Care Plus model. TITLE III focuses on improving rural representation by including it on the CMS Rural Health Council. TITLE III focuses on improving rural representation by ensuring inclusion of rural expertise on the CMS Rural Health Council and collaboration with the Health Care Payment Learning and Action Network. It also emphasizes rural representation on the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission and the Medicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission. The text focuses on amending the Social Security Act to include at least two members representing rural areas in the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission and the Medicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission. Appointments made by the Comptroller General must comply with these requirements. The Medicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission appointments made by the Comptroller General must comply with the requirements of the Social Security Act.
